question.title: Why doesn't javac generate a new .class file after renaming the class?
question.body:
Why doesn't javac generate a new .class file after renaming the class?

My file name is Test.java.

Case #1:

class example {
    public static void main() {}
}

When I compiled this using javac Test.java, it compiled successfully and generated example.class.

Case #2: Then I changed the class name to Example like this:

class Example {
    public static void main() {}
}

I saved the changes in Test.java and recompiled using javac Test.java. However, it did not generate Example.class. The previously generated example.class file is still present in the directory, and no new .class file was created.

Why is javac not generating Example.class even after changing the class name?

I expect that when I compile Test.java using javac Test.java, the generated .class file should match the class name defined inside the file â€” whether it's example or Example. But after changing the class name from example to Example and recompiling, Example.class was not generated, and only the old example.class file remained. Why is this happening?

answers.body:
Because you're on a case insensitive file system (such as macs, configured out of the box), and this kind of operation isn't supported. javac would have to have code to explicitly detect this exotic condition and act differently.

You should file your complaints with your OS vendor, not with javac. Javac simply tells the OS "I want to write to Example.class please" and the OS is the one that 'messes this up' (it's actually specified behaviour) and instead opens a file handle to write to the already existing example.class.

Javac would have to go out of its way to first ask the OS to delete the file before creating it, an extra step with extra potential issues only for this very specific case. Javac.. doesn't. Almost no tool does this.

question_comments.body: @aled: most (probably all) IDEs require the source file name match the class (and also path to match the package) but javac does not
To better understand the previous comment, it may help to see minimal reproducible example.
The class name inside the file must match the name of the file too. You are probably confusing the compiler.
You'll need to provide more info like what java version, what OS etc. For my old linux VM running JDK 11 it works as you expect.
